# List of moments of inertia

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

In [physics](/wiki/Physics "Physics") and [applied
mathematics](/wiki/Applied_mathematics "Applied mathematics"), the mass
[moment of inertia](/wiki/Moment_of_inertia "Moment of inertia"), usually
denoted by I, measures the extent to which an object resists rotational
acceleration about a particular axis, and is the rotational analogue to mass.
Mass moments of inertia have [units](/wiki/Physical_unit "Physical unit") of
[dimension](/wiki/Dimensional_analysis "Dimensional analysis") ML2([mass] ×
[length]2). It should not be confused with the [second moment of
area](/wiki/Second_moment_of_area "Second moment of area"), which is used in
beam calculations. The mass moment of inertia is often also known as the
rotational inertia, and sometimes as the angular mass.

For simple objects with geometric symmetry, one can often determine the moment
of inertia in an exact [closed-form expression](/wiki/Closed-form_expression
"Closed-form expression"). Typically this occurs when the [mass
density](/wiki/Mass_density "Mass density") is constant, but in some cases the
density can vary throughout the object as well. In general, it may not be
straightforward to symbolically express the moment of inertia of shapes with
more complicated mass distributions and lacking symmetry. When calculating
moments of inertia, it is useful to remember that it is an additive function
and exploit the [parallel axis](/wiki/Parallel_axis_theorem "Parallel axis
theorem") and [perpendicular axis theorems](/wiki/Perpendicular_axis_theorem
"Perpendicular axis theorem").

This article mainly considers symmetric mass distributions, with constant
density throughout the object, and the axis of rotation is taken to be through
the [center of mass](/wiki/Center_of_mass "Center of mass") unless otherwise
specified.

## Moments of
inertia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_moments_of_inertia&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Moments of inertia")]

Following are scalar moments of inertia. In general, the moment of inertia is
a tensor, see below.

Description | Figure | Moment(s) of inertia  
---|---|---  
Point mass _m_ at a distance _r_ from the axis of rotation. A point mass does not have a moment of inertia around its own axis, but using the [parallel axis theorem](/wiki/Parallel_axis_theorem "Parallel axis theorem") a moment of inertia around a distant axis of rotation is achieved. | [![PointInertia.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/PointInertia.svg/170px-PointInertia.svg.png)](/wiki/File:PointInertia.svg) |  I = m r 2 {\displaystyle I=mr^{2}} ![I=mr^{2}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dc416bcccf5f63d22af13befd74e5c653ab82f1b)  
Two point masses, _M_ and _m_ , with [reduced mass](/wiki/Reduced_mass "Reduced mass") _μ_ and separated by a distance, _x_ about an axis passing through the center of mass of the system and perpendicular to the line joining the two particles. |  |  I = M m M + m x 2 = μ x 2 {\displaystyle I={\frac {Mm}{M\\!+\\!m}}x^{2}=\mu x^{2}} ![I={\\frac {Mm}{M\\!+\\!m}}x^{2}=\\mu x^{2}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5a3f98322be3c9841fd3da6d904ee0d8b851c51b)  
[Rod](/wiki/Rod_\(geometry\) "Rod \(geometry\)") of length _L_ and mass _m_ , rotating about its center. This expression assumes that the rod is an infinitely thin (but rigid) wire. This is a special case of the thin rectangular plate with axis of rotation at the center of the plate, with _w_ = _L_ and _h_ = _0_. | [![Moment of inertia rod center.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Moment_of_inertia_rod_center.svg/170px-Moment_of_inertia_rod_center.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_rod_center.svg) |  I c e n t e r = m L 2 12 {\displaystyle I_{\mathrm {center} }={\frac {mL^{2}}{12}}\,\\!} ![{\\displaystyle I_{\\mathrm {center} }={\\frac {mL^{2}}{12}}\\,\\!}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dda6f69626497cb772c888150ef4706aeae6747e) [1]  
[Rod](/wiki/Rod_\(geometry\) "Rod \(geometry\)") of length _L_ and mass _m_ , rotating about one end. This expression assumes that the rod is an infinitely thin (but rigid) wire. ## List of 3D inertia
tensors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_moments_of_inertia&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: List of 3D inertia tensors")]

This list of [moment of inertia
tensors](/wiki/Moment_of_inertia#The_inertia_tensor "Moment of inertia") is
given for [principal axes](/wiki/Principal_axis_theorem "Principal axis
theorem") of each object.

To obtain the scalar moments of inertia _I_ above, the tensor moment of
inertia **I** is projected along some axis defined by a [unit
vector](/wiki/Unit_vector "Unit vector") **n** according to the formula:

     n ⋅ I ⋅ n ≡ n i I i j n j , {\displaystyle \mathbf {n} \cdot \mathbf {I} \cdot \mathbf {n} \equiv n_{i}I_{ij}n_{j}\,,} ![\\mathbf {n} \\cdot \\mathbf {I} \\cdot \\mathbf {n} \\equiv n_{i}I_{ij}n_{j}\\,,](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/572551dd3a3634eaf12b9bd2201366fcbab652dc)

where the dots indicate [tensor contraction](/wiki/Tensor_contraction "Tensor
contraction") and we have used the [Einstein summation
convention](/wiki/Einstein_summation_convention "Einstein summation
convention"). In the above table, **n** would be the unit [Cartesian
basis](/wiki/Cartesian_coordinate_system#Representing_a_vector_in_the_standard_basis
"Cartesian coordinate system") **e** _x_ , **e** _y_ , **e** _z_ to obtain _I
x_, _I y_, _I z_ respectively.

Description | Figure | Moment of inertia tensor  
---|---|---  
Solid [sphere](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere") of radius _r_ and mass _m_ | [![Moment of inertia solid sphere.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Moment_of_inertia_solid_sphere.svg/180px-Moment_of_inertia_solid_sphere.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_solid_sphere.svg) |  I = [ 2 5 m r 2 0 0 0 2 5 m r 2 0 0 0 2 5 m r 2 ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {2}{5}}mr^{2}&0&0\\\0&{\frac {2}{5}}mr^{2}&0\\\0&0&{\frac {2}{5}}mr^{2}\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {2}{5}}mr^{2}&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {2}{5}}mr^{2}&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {2}{5}}mr^{2}\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/52c780991451031f075e73210fd5b0e042bfd1c4)  
Hollow sphere of radius _r_ and mass _m_ | [![Moment of inertia hollow sphere.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Moment_of_inertia_hollow_sphere.svg/180px-Moment_of_inertia_hollow_sphere.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_hollow_sphere.svg) |  I = [ 2 3 m r 2 0 0 0 2 3 m r 2 0 0 0 2 3 m r 2 ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {2}{3}}mr^{2}&0&0\\\0&{\frac {2}{3}}mr^{2}&0\\\0&0&{\frac {2}{3}}mr^{2}\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {2}{3}}mr^{2}&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {2}{3}}mr^{2}&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {2}{3}}mr^{2}\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/915349e7bd25f5b776e8c1b09915f1915e2a4653)  
Solid [ellipsoid](/wiki/Ellipsoid "Ellipsoid") of semi-axes _a_ , _b_ , _c_ and mass _m_ | [![Ellipsoide.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ellipsoide.png/180px-Ellipsoide.png)](/wiki/File:Ellipsoide.png) |  I = [ 1 5 m ( b 2 + c 2 ) 0 0 0 1 5 m ( a 2 + c 2 ) 0 0 0 1 5 m ( a 2 + b 2 ) ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {1}{5}}m(b^{2}+c^{2})&0&0\\\0&{\frac {1}{5}}m(a^{2}+c^{2})&0\\\0&0&{\frac {1}{5}}m(a^{2}+b^{2})\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {1}{5}}m\(b^{2}+c^{2}\)&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {1}{5}}m\(a^{2}+c^{2}\)&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {1}{5}}m\(a^{2}+b^{2}\)\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bd0dbfcb413587a9e4b3a399c3cb80e536c60663)  
[Right circular cone](/wiki/Right_circular_cone "Right circular cone") with radius _r_ , height _h_ and mass _m_ , about the apex | [![Moment of inertia cone.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Moment_of_inertia_cone.svg/180px-Moment_of_inertia_cone.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_cone.svg) |  I = [ 3 5 m h 2 + 3 20 m r 2 0 0 0 3 5 m h 2 + 3 20 m r 2 0 0 0 3 10 m r 2 ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {3}{5}}mh^{2}+{\frac {3}{20}}mr^{2}&0&0\\\0&{\frac {3}{5}}mh^{2}+{\frac {3}{20}}mr^{2}&0\\\0&0&{\frac {3}{10}}mr^{2}\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {3}{5}}mh^{2}+{\\frac {3}{20}}mr^{2}&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {3}{5}}mh^{2}+{\\frac {3}{20}}mr^{2}&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {3}{10}}mr^{2}\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f3c9f5caf108f64dcd9b5d00d67074c488edd344)  
Solid cuboid of width w, height h, depth d, and mass m |  [![180x](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/eb/Moment_of_inertia_solid_rectangular_prism.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_solid_rectangular_prism.png "180x") |  I = [ 1 12 m ( h 2 + d 2 ) 0 0 0 1 12 m ( w 2 + d 2 ) 0 0 0 1 12 m ( w 2 + h 2 ) ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {1}{12}}m(h^{2}+d^{2})&0&0\\\0&{\frac {1}{12}}m(w^{2}+d^{2})&0\\\0&0&{\frac {1}{12}}m(w^{2}+h^{2})\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(h^{2}+d^{2}\)&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(w^{2}+d^{2}\)&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(w^{2}+h^{2}\)\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ee50feeecc84360e363188a9c32c67c5b2e0f627)  
Slender rod along y-axis of length _l_ and mass _m_ about end |  [![Moment of inertia rod end.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Moment_of_inertia_rod_end.svg/100px-Moment_of_inertia_rod_end.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_rod_end.svg) |  I = [ 1 3 m l 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 1 3 m l 2 ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {1}{3}}ml^{2}&0&0\\\0&0&0\\\0&0&{\frac {1}{3}}ml^{2}\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {1}{3}}ml^{2}&0&0\\\\0&0&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {1}{3}}ml^{2}\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/610a2c8d13c438436965f1f62dc3d42162e52cf5)  
Slender rod along y-axis of length _l_ and mass _m_ about center |  [![Moment of inertia rod center.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Moment_of_inertia_rod_center.svg/180px-Moment_of_inertia_rod_center.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_rod_center.svg) |  I = [ 1 12 m l 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 1 12 m l 2 ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {1}{12}}ml^{2}&0&0\\\0&0&0\\\0&0&{\frac {1}{12}}ml^{2}\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {1}{12}}ml^{2}&0&0\\\\0&0&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {1}{12}}ml^{2}\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/caa2cdcd556f0dcfefa331af9f5dad7c3c93ae96)  
Solid cylinder of radius r, height h and mass m | [![Moment of inertia solid cylinder.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Moment_of_inertia_solid_cylinder.svg/180px-Moment_of_inertia_solid_cylinder.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_solid_cylinder.svg) |  I = [ 1 12 m ( 3 r 2 + h 2 ) 0 0 0 1 12 m ( 3 r 2 + h 2 ) 0 0 0 1 2 m r 2 ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {1}{12}}m(3r^{2}+h^{2})&0&0\\\0&{\frac {1}{12}}m(3r^{2}+h^{2})&0\\\0&0&{\frac {1}{2}}mr^{2}\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(3r^{2}+h^{2}\)&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(3r^{2}+h^{2}\)&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {1}{2}}mr^{2}\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fcc0f3020a0ae2b3036d48e13a6db66fe07c9ed9)  
Thick-walled cylindrical tube with open ends, of inner radius _r_ 1, outer radius _r_ 2, length _h_ and mass _m_ | [![Moment of inertia thick cylinder h.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Moment_of_inertia_thick_cylinder_h.svg/180px-Moment_of_inertia_thick_cylinder_h.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moment_of_inertia_thick_cylinder_h.svg) |  I = [ 1 12 m ( 3 ( r 1 2 + r 2 2 ) + h 2 ) 0 0 0 1 12 m ( 3 ( r 1 2 + r 2 2 ) + h 2 ) 0 0 0 1 2 m ( r 1 2 + r 2 2 ) ] {\displaystyle I={\begin{bmatrix}{\frac {1}{12}}m(3({r_{1}}^{2}+{r_{2}}^{2})+h^{2})&0&0\\\0&{\frac {1}{12}}m(3({r_{1}}^{2}+{r_{2}}^{2})+h^{2})&0\\\0&0&{\frac {1}{2}}m({r_{1}}^{2}+{r_{2}}^{2})\end{bmatrix}}} ![I={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(3\({r_{1}}^{2}+{r_{2}}^{2}\)+h^{2}\)&0&0\\\\0&{\\frac {1}{12}}m\(3\({r_{1}}^{2}+{r_{2}}^{2}\)+h^{2}\)&0\\\\0&0&{\\frac {1}{2}}m\({r_{1}}^{2}+{r_{2}}^{2}\)\\end{bmatrix}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1fd8a577878924b6b5c3dffc365ec619e918cd0c)
